Award.AwardTitle: Revealing the Physics and Dynamics of the Unique Galaxy Cluster Merger Abell 2146
Award.AbstractNarration:
The aim of the proposal is to conduct cutting-edge simulations of Abell 2146, which consists of two merging, massive galaxy clusters that are viewed close to the plane of the sky soon after their first collision. Dark matter dominates the merger's total mass, and its distribution has been revealed. The normal baryonic matter in the merger is hot, and its distribution is known from X-ray measurements. Due to the merger's favorable viewing angle and youth, these distributions differ markedly. This provides a rare opportunity to use the proposed simulations to place strong constraints on the merger's material and dynamics. As an added bonus, the simulations will investigate why this cluster merger lacks radio emission, in stark contrast to its ubiquity in other mergers.

The PI will continue her established efforts to recruit local high school students from underrepresented groups into her institution. She will also develop a series of software-tools workshops for students and faculty at her institution.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has greatly increased our understanding of the system Abell 2146 – a collision between massive galaxy clusters, each containing many hundreds of galaxies. In particular the research involved data analysis and modeling, and computer simulations of this rare system. In other projects, our collaboration made observational maps of the system’s luminous matter seen in the aftermath of the collision, using telescopes including Hubble Space Telescope (HST) and Chandra X-ray Observatory (CXO) to collect electromagnetic radiation that travels for several billion years to reach us. Most of the mass in the Universe cannot be seen directly using telescopes; a critical part of this project involved carefully mapping the system’s dark matter. This was achieved using the fact that mass warps space-time, resulting in so-called gravitational lensing: light bundles traveling to us from thousands of very distant galaxies, and passing close to the system, are distorted and even multiply imaged. The research included identifying multiply imaged galaxies, using data from HST and the ground-based Gemini-N and Subaru telescopes. These lensed galaxies were then used in a model to pinpoint the dark matter.

The project resulted in different types of new computer simulations of Abell 2146, designed to match features in the maps of luminous and dark matter. The computer simulations provide information on the mass distributions and motions of the galaxy clusters before they collided, and predictions for the future evolution and final fate of the system. Most of the luminous matter in galaxy clusters is in the form of hot X-ray emitting gas. Our collaboration is using the simulation results to aid in the interpretation of new deeper CXO maps of Abell 2146, primarily to reveal and quantify the physical processes operating in the hot gas. 

The lensing signatures and detectability of galaxy clusters, such as those composing Abell 2146, were also investigated in a cosmological context. This involved ray-tracing bundles of light through large-volume computer simulations that capture galaxy and cluster-mass structures as well as the large-scale cosmic web that underpins the Universe. Most large-volume computer simulations only account for dark matter and its gravity. In our study we ray-traced through the BAHAMAS simulations that in addition include prescriptions for the physics of luminous matter, and also allow for very abundant particles called neutrinos to have non-zero mass. 

The project funding also enabled an exciting theoretical investigation of transient brightening of stars in our Galaxy by stellar-mass binary black holes (BBH) acting as microlenses. An important conclusion is that microlensing searches are sensitive to BBH with larger separations than gravitational wave searches, suggesting that the techniques might permit the discovery of BBH created via different mechanisms. 

Several graduate students and numerous undergraduate students from several US universities have participated in the project, many from underrepresented groups. As well as training in astrophysics, the project has resulted in students acquiring and developing skills such as computing and team-work, preparing students for academic and non-academic paths. Most of the undergraduates are now in graduate school, two as NSF GRFP awardees. The students who completed their PhDs are postdoctoral researchers or work in science/technology/education fields. The results of the project have been presented in PhD theses, senior undergraduate theses and scientific papers. In addition, the results have been shared with diverse audiences of children and adults, for example via presentations at universities and scientific meetings, museums, schools and during community engagement activities.
